Each sip begs another and keeps you coming back for more. Easily one of the best in the style. Delicious stuff.

12 ounce can into tulip glass, canned on 3/21/2016. Pours slightly hazy golden yellow color with a 2 finger fairly dense and fluffy white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big sour lemon, lime, green apple, white grape, peach, pineapple, sea salt, coriander, wheat, cracker, bread, herbal, light vinegar/funk, and yeast earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity/acidic yeast, salt/spice, and moderate pale malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big sour lemon, lime, green apple, white grape, peach, pineapple, sea salt, coriander, wheat, cracker, bread, herbal, light vinegar/funk, and yeast earthiness. Moderate fruity/lactic sourness on the finish; with lingering notes of sour lemon, lime, green apple, white grape, peach, pineapple, sea salt, coriander, wheat, cracker, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. A very enjoyable offering.

This one has a misty, deep egg yolk yellow blonde colour with nuances of green and orange covered in clouds of yeast, yet very transparent (almost colourless) around the edges; egg-white, very thin and unstable head, decreasing immediately and all but disappearing after a short while. Aroma of wheat, lots of lactic acidity (unsweetened yoghurt, sour cream, goat cheese), something faintly salty (seaweed), the expected coriander, stale sweat, sourdough, sorrel leaves, strong suggestion of Sauerkraut (sour, fermented cabbage and meat), something vaguely egg-like and apple peel. Interesting taste: kicks off with a sharp, refreshing lemon acidity, turning into a more subdued but dominant lactic acidity (sour milk), still medium carbonation in spite of the lack of head or fizz; a basic wheat sourishness underlies along with a hint of bready barley malts; drying coriander effect is there, but less ¬íobnoxious¬í than in many Belgian witbier examples; smooth, mellow and supple mouthfeel, salt presence is restrained and mainly structural, as it should be, though it can be noticed on the sides of the tongue. Finishes in a slightly drying coriander taste along with equally drying sourness, but nothing too corrosive: it is a gentle, soft, ¬ílong¬í and ¬ídeep¬í tartness as in a Berliner Weisse. Much like Sauerkraut, to which this would be an ideal companion, this is clearly an acquired taste, and there still aren¬ít many congeners to compare it with; the Sauerkraut aroma is admittedly typical for the style, but I still have to get used to it.  I do like the actual taste of it, though: totally quenching, refreshing, crisp and very interesting, too bad for the lack of head, though.

Faint bitterness, relatively dry, and the tartness does tend to accumulate with volume, which is good, but we¬íre still nowhere near a pucker. Coriander and citric elements are largely absent - this is a heavy, full American Wheat, though brewed for a more modern palate than those targeted by brewpubs fifteen and twenty years ago. Touch slimy with wheat, but strips the palate efficiently. Overall fresh, clean, and lively, without obvious alcohol; there¬ís some tension for me here, as this is not as bold or memorable as the more traditional Gose I treasure (the lacto is not complex at all and really needs to jump), but I¬íd probably drink more of this in a sitting (three or four with no problem, should have enough total acidity by then). Trotzdem goseanna! I do dig the beer, and it¬ís got that great session-with-food vibe.

I poured a 12oz can into a goblet. It was canned on 6/16/14 and cost $3.20 ($0.27 per ounce).

Appearance: Gold hue over a hazy body. Plenty of initial carbonation, but settles down quickly. Pours to a small, white, soapy head which completely dissipates and leaves no lacing.

Smell: Slightly mild nose with distinct sour candy scent and a hint of lemon.

Taste: Everyone loves sours, but up until recently it was only the really expensive, rare, high alcohol sour beers that were en vogue. Now sessionable sours like Berlinner Weise and Gose are all the rage. That¬ís okay, because they¬íre easier to come by and actually quite affordable; Westbrook Gose being a good example of what I mean. This might be best described as alcoholic lemonade (authentic, homemade, hand-squeezed lemonade ¬ñ not that mass-produced stuff that¬ís just a chemical cocktail). The palette is simplistic and repetitive in that there¬ís pretty much only two flavor characters here: a tartness with a slight lemony taste and a sourness like candy. Nothing in the way of genuine malt or hop character, though those traits aren¬ít meant to stand out anyway. The salt presence accentuates the tartness ¬ñ there¬ís no astringency like that of sea water. 

Drinkability: It¬ís nice to see low ABV beers that are truly refreshing like Westbrook Gose come in cans, as this is the kind of beer you can enjoy straight from the container without missing out on much of the experience. This is a very easy beer to drink as the mouthfeel is thin and crisp, but never becomes flat. The tartness and sourness are not challenging to get past (especially when enjoyed cold). At only 4% ABV this is an ideal session beer for summer.

text: UPDATED: SEP 4, 2013 From a nice little can. Pours a murky/heavily cloudy yellow with no head and thus no lacing. Not great looking at all. Aroma is fresh with coriander and light citrus. Taste is again citric, acid with a small salty aftertought. Body is light and the drink is quenching. Not overly complex but still somewhat true to style. This isn¬ít the best gose I¬íve had but not the worst either.

Can. Yellow colored pour with a white head. Funky smell, citrus, musty, yeast smell. Taste is pretty good - it tastes like lemonade with some kinda funk that I cannot pinpoint, but damn if this stuff isnt refreshing. Its 4% so I feel like I could drink it all day. Really a good beer, something I am not sure I have ever had before. Finally something unique in the world of craft beer. A rarity now-a-days.

10th August 2013ChrisO¬ís Pre GBBF ¬íAre You Scottish?¬í tasting. Very hazy gold beer. Very light palate. Light sourish note, woody geueze. Light winey sourness. Light spice and seltzer mineral finish.

Can from alexsdad06. Poured a cloudy yellow color with a large white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Good aroma of wheat and spice. Medium to abundant body with tingly texture and soft carbonation. Good sour citrus flavor with a complex sweet & sour finish of medium duration. Interesting complex brew.

12 oz. can. Cloudy gold with thin head. Nose is sour peach, tart wheat and salt. Flavor starts tart wheat then transitions to a slaty cracker. True to style with a tart finish and dry texture.
Good and refreshing on a warm summer afternoon. Decent

From 12oz can. 

Pours a cloudy, murky, grapefruit juice color. In fact, if I did not know I had poured a beer I'd guess it was grapefruit juice. Very citrusy aroma. Taste is of a sour with more citrus. Aftertaste is all sour. 

Probably a good example of a gose, but not my cup of tea. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled:Hazy pale yellow. Thick head. Tart aroma with lots of citrus; lemons, lime, oranges. Tart, sour flavour with notes of lime, grapefruit and orange juice. Subtle, growing saltiness in the background. Different, refreshing and interesting.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2015 8/23/13. 12oz can from a sixer, from Warehouse in Valdosta. Pours a hazy, nearly murky, orange with a big, fluffy off-white head that sizzles away too fast. Sour acidity hits the nose straight away, plenty of lemon, and lots of cereal grain, specifically Cheerios, maybe a dash of an herbal aspect if you search for it. Sour flavor, big acidity, lemon juice, more lingering doughy cereal grains, Cheerios, etc. More salt and a touch more spice comes through in the flavor. Sour, a touch salty, lingering graininess, pretty tasty down here in the south.

light sour note, wheat malt quality. tart, effervescence in the nose. turbid dark straw color. pours with generous head that falls quickly to zero head. sharply sour, lactic/acidic, a light cereal note in the finish. dry. really refreshing. the salt and spice are done very subtly. you can perceive a touch of salinity/mineral taste in the middle to finish.

Bomber. Pours hazy golden with quickly dissipating white head. Aroma is citric and slightly funky. A little wheat and yeast coming out as well. Taste brings immediate tartness, followed by a more defined lemon flavor. That get subsumed by the salt in this one, which is certainly welcome. I feel like several goses I¬íve had recently fall short in this regard. Palate is spritzy and drying. Finish is lemon and some residual wheat/grain. I saw this one was in cans...may have to pick up a bunch. Really enjoyed this.

Can. Sour apples, cow piss nose. Hazy apple juice color, thin filmy head. Mildly sour initial / the tang hits the upper palate and sides of the tongue, like light pickle juice / final dissipates and leaves a light crackery note. Thin and astringent. Coriander doesn¬ít really emerge. Interesting and refreshing.

Can. Pours a hazy gold with quickly dissipating cream colored head. Aroma of spice and hints of lemon. Taste is very unique, with strong sour and salty components. Reminds me of salt and vinegar chips.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2015 Re-rated - Can. Pours a cloudy golden-orange color with white head. Tart, salty, lemon, spicy aromas. Salty, sour, citrus, sour lemonade flavors.  My previous rating from 2013 had this as a 3.1, but I¬íve upped to a 3.7.  I have come to enjoy goses more over the past 2 years, and this one is certainly one of the better versions of the style.

The color was like liquid gold, pale, yet somehow deep, due to the murkiness of the body. The foam fizzed briefly to for a thin floating head before fading away, and leaving behind a still liquid that looked like raw sugarcane juice. The smell was sour and biting, and somewhat reminiscent of a Lambic. The taste showed off both the sourness and salt, as this tasted more like an unsweetened cider than any other beer I have had before. I have had the German Gose a long time ago, but I hon¬ít recall it being this bold. Very light and refreshing to drink, and the 4% alcohol made it quite easy to drink. The finish was a lingering, puckering sourness. I only picked a single can this time, but I think I will get more, while the days are long, and the summer sun still lurks about.
Gose in a can. Poured a hazy yellow color with a small sized head. Wheat, salty, tart wheat, citrus, and coriander.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2014 12 oz. can from Growlers. Pours a cloudy golden color with a huge fluffy white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma has a sour citrus, hints of vinegar, salty with some herbal spice. The sour character leans toward the lemon side of citrus. The flavor is initially very tart/sour lemon citrus and acidic before becoming briny mid-palate. Mild herbal spicy notes with a light amount of toasted bread. This is an interesting beer that I will revisit outdoors in the hot afternoon sun.

Bottle from √òlbutikken, Copenhagen, bottled 4/14/13Hazy blond color with small head. Mild aroma, sourdough and lactic acid, light plastic. The mouthfeel is lean, very dry; light breadish flavor, quite sharp acidity for the style, more lemony than lactic, hiding the possible salt; it also has a very light breadish flavor. The final is also lightly astringent.An aggressive example. Refreshing. But it could have some more complexity.
Bottle at Chris O¬ís pre-GBBF shindig, 2013. Pale yellow pour with a white head. Grapefruit and lychee aroma. Quite a sour flavour. Green apple, a little cherry. Not bad.

The tagline on the can is Sour-Salty-Delicious. That could pretty much sum up my review. Had the original bomber and was excited to see this in cans and ordered a case to mule back to MS. Smells funky, but sourness matched with fresh grain, the coriander, a little salt makes for a really tasty brew. Well done.
Smelled terrible, tasted great. Smells like stinky cheese and sweat. Tasted sour, refreshing and crisp. Lemon, vinegar, and just a touch of savory flavors. Odd and tasty.

12oz can. Probably a first to see a sourish beer in a can but I was going to pour it into a pint glass anyways so what does it matter?! Hazy light yellow apricot color. Lemon and yeast aromas. Nice effervescence. At points this reminds me a little bit of a carbonated citrus soda it has that many bubbles. Nice citrus working throughout and a faint funkiness with some cheese and saltiness working in there to balance things out. Nice, not overly complex but plenty entertaining.
Pours the color of yellow grapefruit juice with a disappearing white head. Sour, salty, wheat, floral notes and a background flavor of beeswax
22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, citric and light yeasty. Salty, citric and light fruity. Bitter and dry citric finish.

Bottled. An unclear dark yellow beer with a fast disappearing white head. The aroma has notes of wheat, lemons, salt, and coriander. The flavor is acidic with notes of salt, wheat, brettanomyces, straw, and hints of coriander, leading to a tart finish. Very refreshing.

Bottle. Almost clear hay yellow liquid with small white head. Aroma of lemon peel, herbs, grain, lacto and bread. Taste is dry and medium to high sour with notes of herbs, light salt, lemon and bread. Light to medium bodied with medium carbonation. Nice, not as salty as I expected.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear yellow - white head. light acid, salty notes, freshness, light malty, apple, pear notes, light spicy coriander notes, wheaty acid, sour apple freshness.

Slightly cloudy, watery gold, minimal white head.
Sour lemon/grain malt aroma
Very tart, puckering lemon, wheat taste....salty...
Very good.

Pours a super cloudy straw yellow with a small bubbly white head. Some nice tart berry notes on the nose, wheat, coriander, light lemon notes, and slightly grassy. Mhmm, tastes like a very tart somewhat salty lemonade. nice wheat and spicy taste, some straw and grassy notes, and some other citrusy fruit notes. Great beer for hot weather, and I could see this pairing well with seafood.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2015 12 oz. can. Pale, cloudy yellow color, with a big, fluffy, off-white head. The aroma is nice lemonade, white bread, and coriander, with some notes of mango and bitter oranges. The flavor is tart, pretty salty, with some citrusy sweetness. Very light body, with a very acidic mouthfeel. This is an pretty approachable sour beer; fairly refreshing and drinkable. If anything can be held against this, it is that it is too salty.

Believe the hype. These cans flew off the shelves throughout Atlanta. Pours a cloudy pear with slight white head. Scent is berries, grapes, and sea air. Taste is a funky mix of sour and salt with a barely there sweet finish. Light bodied and bubbly which goes well with the beers other characteristics. Cans - Ale Yeah! - Decatur, GA
Bottle.Musty lemon and light briny aroma. Hazy golden yellow with a small white head. Tart lactic lemon and salty flavor. Light body, soft carbonation.
Bottle. Salt, lactic acid and lemon aroma. Pale yellow with small head. Lightly sweet-strong tart lemon and salty wheat malt flavor. Nice body. Very tasty.

The aroma is earth, hay, lemon, salt. The appearance is hazy light yellow, thin white head. The flavor is sour, lemon, slat, cereal garins. The finish is salty, lemon. Medium in body. Nice representation of the style.

Bottled. A decent gose but some of these ratings seem based on the brewery and its deservedly excellent rep. Slightly cloudy yellow. Spicy smell. Sour peppery tart lemon. Good interpretation of a gose.
Last Beer of many sampled at The Festival. A good one to end on. Straw colored pour, lemon tartness, touch of salt. Simple but very good, refreshing tartness. Really nice
Poured from the bottle. Color is hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma is quite tart. Taste is also tart, then you get the saltiness. Its not to heavy, but you know its there. Definitely worth a try.

None existent aroma and thin, straw yellow appearance, thin but enjoyably salty taste and barely there mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2015 Sampled at THE FESTIVAL 2013 in Maine with Andrew, Jay and Kramer. Pours a light hazy golden body with thin white lacing. Aroma is tart wheat, limeade and salt. Mouthfeel is very nicely balanced between sweet tart, wheat, limes and salt. Very clean, tart and crisp. Great Gose. Super sessionable especially given the level of tartness.

Pours a pale golden color with a finger of white fizzy foam. The nose is bright with salty lime notes,rustic light fruity wheat notes and a touch of minerality almost tin like but in a good way. The palate follows the nose with nice crisp tartness and white grape tannins cutting into a round fruity pebble cereal backbone. I adore this beer... paired perfectly with a homemade lamb curry.
Draft. Pours hazy yellow gold with a white head. Nice tart lemony citric base, with low to medium sweetness and relatively restrained salt, on a nice clean wheaty base. Good stuff.

pour @ THE festival, maine. clear pale yellow with a short-lived head. bright key-lime pie, lemons, spicy, salt and a certain greeness - vegetal-like. nice acidic profile. salty - tad too much that is. light carbonation, light body. quenching and nciely done.
Pours a cloudy/hazy pale yellow with a perfectly distributed white head. The aroma is lemon, orange and coriander. Wow.

Wonderful bready smell mixed with ocean water. Initially very sour on top middle of tongue mellowing into a seaweed salty flavor. Yeasty finish with a lingering sourdough roll flavor. Very refreshing beer.

Bottle from Liquor express. Pours yellow with an inch of white foam. Lots of citrus and salt on the nose. The sour citrus dominates the tongue with a kind of salt lock aftertaste. Seems like a great beer for the summer. Hard to believe there¬ís this much flavor from a 4% beer.

Nice bright aroma of citrus and wheat. You can tell it is zippy by the aroma. Taste is very tart but amazingly refreshing. Great summertime beer. Wow, I'm gonna go get more 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Gingerman. Pours cloudy yellow gold with a thin white head. Aromas of salt, wheat, citrus and a slight musty, earthy funkiness. Taste is tart, bright and acidic with the perfect amount of salinity and subtle hints of wheat. Great puckering finish. Super clean and very tasty; refreshing, well balanced and very well done. Loved this and could drink loads of it.

The Sampler, Brooklyn 22oz ($8): Hazy orange/yellow with a white head. Aroma is sour lemon, with a hint of vinegar, along with some weird funk (sort of like vegetable funk). Taste is moderately sour (easily the most sour gose of those that I¬íve had). Salt is pretty minimal. As per usual, there is a wonderful gose aftertaste. Some nice lemon notes. I am really glad this style is making a comeback.

Hazy golden yellow pour with wispy white that quickly dissipates. Sour lemon, wheat aromas. My first gose, so I had no idea what to expect, but this is refreshing and unique. Bubbly, champagne like mouthfeel that opens with citrus fruty sweetness that turns sour and a bit dry. Not for everyday drinking, probably a good Sunday brunch beverage, but excellent, I will look for more.

Tap. Pours pale hazy yellow with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with no lacing. Aroma is sour lactic acid, salt, spicy hops and wheat malt. Flavor is crisp malt, salt, sour spicy wheat malt and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
Draft at The Festival. Cloudybyellow color, white head. Aroma and tastenof earthy straw. Decent.

P: Gently carbonation streaming throughout the hazed pale straw body topped with a fast fading frothy bubble head. 

S: Tart lemon, coriander, damp wheat, canned dog food aroma, and pale malt. 

T/M: Lip puckering sour lemon juice, salt, lime, tonic water, and soggy wheat. Acidic zesty light body that really make the flavors shine. 

O: A fantastic recreation of the style. I love the sourness with the salty wheat. Flavors were well balanced and complementing. Glad I had a chance to enjoy this.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 Tasp at Sourfest. Golden pour with a rocky white head. Salty, lactic nose with a hint of spice and some subtle sweet grain. Flavor is moisture sucking dryness, lactic acidity, wheat graininess, citrus and a hint of sweetness. Mighty tasty Gose.

Tap at Ginger Man. Cloudy yellow pour with lots of very fine white head. The nose is...strange. Funky sea salt aromas dominate with a tart citrus note underneath. Lemon/severely underripe mandarin orange. A lot of the same transfers to the palate. Moderate sourness, lemon zest, Finishes with a salty little kick. My first gose but very tasty.

Not a whole lot on the nose, brett, lemon, slight sweetness.  Taste is good amount of sourness, a bit funky, fairly dry, salty.  You do get some of the wheat flavors coming through.  Finishes with a nice clean tart palate.

Bottle.  Cloudy yellow pour.  Tangy acidic nose with some coriander notes.  Mostly just really nice lactic acidity.  Flavor delivers more of the same.  Great bright acidity with some coriander notes and just a hint of salt.  Really nice Gose.
Best gose Ive ever had.  Really nice spiced beer with just the right amount of salt to add something to the finish that makes you want more.  Just tasty and unique with lemon and coriander.
on draft at brewery, absolutely loved this one, great huge carbonation and nice salty finish, very tart refreshing, love it

Aroma: Lemon, Avgolemono.
Appearance: Hazy yellow/gold with thin white head.
Taste: Fairly intense sour taste, with a saltiness.
Palate: Very lively, thin body. Dry and tart finish, that dissipates quickly, leaving me wanting more. 
Overall: Such a cool style of beer; light, lively and refreshing. Not too sour, incredibly refreshing, and so easy to drink. Would love to see this show up in cans, perfect beach beer.

poured a florescent yellow with very little head.  taste of lemon peel, wheat and cilantro.  as my glass came to room temperature, you could could really feel the after taste of sea salt which compliments the sour/wheat extremely well.  another bottle that surprised us..  I like surprised

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2013 Draft.  Poured a hazy straw with a thin white head.  Aroma and flavor were very lemony, tart, acidic, quite clean, lightly briny.  Light palate.  Very refreshing.  Took me a few minutes to adjust, but in the end I liked it a lot.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2013 Bottle shared by a kind soul at PaulUnwin¬ís sour tasting.  Pours a hazy yellow with a white head.  Nose is light malt, citrus, big salt, some pepper, and some sour grapefruit.  Flavor follows: salt and pepper, light citrus, and some sour grapefruit.  Nice interpretation of the style.  

As I get more into the style and gain an appreciation, I went back and rerated it as I see that 1. it is a great representation of the style, 2. they can it, and 3. it is a great hot weather beer.
At sours tasting at Samy¬ís. Funky sour aroma. interesting salty and sweet flavours, sour lemon candy and some spices.

Pours a hazy light gold. Aroma of citrus, wheat. Taste is sour and salty. Finishes very grainy wheat. Not bad, interesting. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2013 Growler... This beer rocks!... Milky straw-colored ale with a small, fizzy, white head that quickly dissipates. The tart, citrusy nose delivers light graininess, flanked by hints of muscadines and scuppernongs, and only a trace of coriander. Medium-bodied with dancing carbonation. Sour, fruity flavor - lemon and under-ripe apricot accompanied by the perfect pinch of salt. Finishes crisp and tart. I would drink this all day, every day. Growler courtesy of Elliesbrown!

Cloudy straw with lacy white head.  Smell is sour with a bit of funk.  Taste is pretty sour, some funky, but the sourness is very clean.  Hint of salt in the finish.  The body is nice, crisp medium carbonation.  Really nice beer considering the price.  This was a hit at our tasting.

Bottle shared by Todd (OSCF) in the Charlotte Phish parking lot   Fantastic parking lot beer.  This gose was super salty, the salt character being more present in this one than in any of the other (few) that I have tried.  Still very refreshing, lots of sour wheat,  a mild citrus character, very minerally.  Kinda like gargling salt water on the palate but still very cleansing and nice.  Would definitely drink again.

Pouring near all of the NYC/VT tents in the campground at BCTC.  Pours a hazed gold with a large white head.  Light tart acid, caramel and toast.  Tart and salty, briny.  Lots of bright acid, briny and full of salinity.  Lovely.  Another beer I could gladly drink all day.  Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2014 Best gose I have had.  Sweet and spicy coriander.  Thanks for sharing, Doug K. Light golden colour, sea salt was refreshing and apparently more healthy.  Full mouthfeel, assertive carbonation. A great complement to the other sour beers of the day.
Review bee-aye 6300.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2014 Pale blonde pour, thumbs worth of head.  Funky sour aroma, tart sour lemon candies, white pepper, sea salt.  Taste is the same - fairly tart, sour and salty.  Slight corriander, lemon rind.  Good summer drinker.
Thanks to Chris.  Pale blonde. Lightly hazy. Nice and tart. Light wheat. Acidity is great through the finish.

22 ounce bottle that poured a very light hazy straw yellow color, aromas of salt, tartness, and some wheat.  Flavors are the same, not overly slaty, not overly sour, not overly wheaty, just a great combination of all three flavors, that were refreshing, and satisfying while I grilled out.  Really great beer.

Bomber from Piggly Wiggly, Myrtle Beach, SC. A very interesting beer indeed. A usual Hefe nose rises from a classic German wheat beer  body of cloudy yellow/off-white deliciousness. While there is little lacing, the beer is true to style being unfiltered and offering some little residue at the bottom of the glass. A mixed bags of flavors hits the palate on first sip, acidic lemon hits the sides of the tongue and throat but instead of some sours, the flavor evolves into a bready, salted peanut taste that is quite unique. I¬ím not sure I could drink this as a session brew but one glass a day should keep the Fall away. Great summer beer.

WOW....this was a surprise but maybe it shouldn¬ít be. Westbrook is doing sours as good as anyone in the US.   I¬ím not really sure of the difference between a gose vs. berliner.  Maybe the high amount of wheat?   Its a perfect summer beer.  4% , cloudy, very little head.  Its actually very salty per style.  Easily the saltiest beer I¬íve ever had but works well this the tart/sourness.  Maybe a touch under carbonated. Maybe the salt that is added kills the head and carbonation.  I dont get any coriander.    Tart, sour, and complex at 4%.  Awesome..  Wish i bought more.

Tap at Funky Buddha. It pours cloudy light orange, with a thick white head (which dissipates after a while). The nose is salt, sweet citrus, sharp lemon and herbal notes. The taste is refreshingly tart, juicy grapefruit, salt, lemon, home-made lemonade, bit of pineapple, light acidity and hint of herb, with a tart finish. Medium body, prickly carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Balance is brilliant. This is light, refreshing and cleanses the palate. There are hardly any beers that taste this good at only 4%. Delicious!
On draft at the Funky Buddha. Light color with a cloudy center. Aroma has slight hints of lemon citrus and sour funk. Flavor is a little salty with a nice tartness on the back end.
Bottle. Pours grapefruit juice. Nose/taste of sea salt, funk, banana, coriander, wheat and citrus. Perfectly crafted for the style. Finishes tart and funky with well-blended sea salt. Medium body.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2012 There¬ís really not much more you could ask for in a summer beer.  Westbrook Gose is refreshing, sessionable, and incredibly fucking tasty to boot.  Tart and tangy as hell, with a noticeable briny bonus on the finish, this beer begs to be consumed as you go about your normal summer day, mowing the lawn, watering the plants, and riding with your brother to the hospital after he¬ís shot himself in the face with a bottle rocket.  (Your brother drinks Bud Platinum and thinks Creed is classic rock, by the way, so your brother is an asshole and deserved the Black Cat to the nostril.)   Anyway, the perky carbonation makes sure the beer doesn¬ít grow cloy or dull, yet doesn¬ít hamper the lingering tart finish.  Mr. Westbrook, sir, please make this brew a regular offering; yeah, sours are trendy and popular and all, but I¬íve never seen such an obscure, alternative beer style create such a broad fan base in just a handful of weeks.  Great beer.
